definitions.definition: to change or make something change from one form, purpose, system, etc. to another
definitions.sensetop: convert somethingconvert something into somethingconvert something to somethingconvert from somethingconvert into/to somethingconvert from something to something

examples.text: They took just nine months to convert the building.
You need to ensure that you've converted the data properly.
The pub is a converted warehouse.
The hotel is going to be converted into a nursing home.
What rate will I get if I convert my dollars into euros?
The system is eco-friendly because the waste heat is converted to electricity.
Japan was at the time still converting from an agricultural economy.
A lot of conventional farmers have converted to organic production.
We've converted from oil to gas central heating.
They live in a converted mill.
to convert securities into shares

definitions.definition: to be able to be changed from one form, purpose, or system to another

examples.text: a sofa that converts into a bed
In fruits, starch converts into sugar.

definitions.definition: to change your religion or beliefs; to make somebody change their religion or beliefs
definitions.sensetop: convert from somethingconvert to somethingconvert from something to somethingconvert somebody from somethingconvert somebody to somethingconvert somebody from something to something

examples.text: He converted from Catholicism 20 years ago.
She converted to Judaism to marry him.
He converted from Christianity to Islam.
Evangelical Christian groups tried to convert local people from their indigenous religions.
She was soon converted to the socialist cause.
Mongolia was converted from shamanism to Buddhism in the late 16th century.
examples.contextForm: convert somebody from something to something

definitions.definition: to change an opinion, a habit, etc.
definitions.sensetop: convert (from something) to somethingconvert somebody (from something) (to something)

examples.text: I've converted to organic food.
I didn't use to like opera but my husband has converted me.
The Prime Minister was in favour of the idea but he never managed to convert the party.
I've never liked opera but you might convert me!

definitions.definition: to score extra points after a try or a touchdown
to speak to people in support of views that they already hold

examples.text: I realize I may be preaching to the converted, but I think he's gorgeous.

wordOrigin: Middle English (in the sense ‘turn round, send in a different direction’): from Old French convertir, based on Latin convertere ‘turn about’, from con- ‘altogether’ + vertere ‘turn’.
